name: Kepler-400
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-400 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-400 is a star with 1.2439999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.15 times its radius. It is located 2312.45 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-400 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-400 b

Kepler-400 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 9.02 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-400.

The mass of Kepler-400 b is 3.19 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-400 b is 1.65 that of Earth. At 3.19 Earth masses, Kepler-400 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-400 c

Kepler-400 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 17.34 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-400.

The mass of Kepler-400 c is 2.51 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-400 c is 1.49 that of Earth. At 2.51 Earth masses, Kepler-400 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-400, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
